properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today into tonight. Snow squalls are expected to intermittently affect the area until Saturday. Snowfall amounts near 5 cm are possible today with an additional 2 to 5 cm possible tonight. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T08:53:03-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected Saturday night and Sunday morning for Central Coast - Coastal Sections, Vancouver Island, Sunshine Coast and Lower Mainland. A cool airmass and low pressure system will slide along coastal B.C. on Saturday. Snow is forecast to begin Saturday night and continue into Sunday. By Sunday afternoon snow will become mixed with rain in many areas. Potential snowfall accumulation varies from 2 to 5 cm for most of the Lower Mainland, the Sunshine Coast, inland sections of western Vancouver Island and for Central Coast - Coastal Sections. Eastern and inland areas of Vancouver Island are most likely to see the highest amounts of snow, with accumulations from 5 to 15 cm, especially above 200 metres; this includes the Malahat Highway. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T04:32:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-22T12:33:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3031644196.2021
Area: North Vancouver Island, East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, West Vancouver Island, Inland Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected Saturday night and Sunday morning for Central Coast - Coastal Sections, Vancouver Island, Sunshine Coast and Lower Mainland. A cool airmass and low pressure system will slide along coastal B.C. on Saturday. Snow is forecast to begin Saturday night and continue into Sunday. By Sunday afternoon snow will become mixed with rain in many areas. Potential snowfall accumulation varies from 2 to 5 cm for most of the Lower Mainland, the Sunshine Coast, inland sections of western Vancouver Island and for Central Coast - Coastal Sections. Eastern and inland areas of Vancouver Island are most likely to see the highest amounts of snow, with accumulations from 5 to 15 cm, especially above 200 metres; this includes the Malahat Highway. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall totalling 15 to 25 cm inland is expected today. Lesser amounts approaching 15 cm are expected near the coast. Locations: Queens and Lunenburg Counties. Time span: continuing into this evening. Remarks: Heavy snowfall will continue into this evening in parts of western Nova Scotia. At this time, the highest amounts are expected over inland areas of Queens and Lunenburg Counties where amounts could reach 25 cm. Closer to the coast, snowfall amounts of generally 10 to 15 cm are expected, with some parts of the coast receiving a mix of rain and snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-22T22:59:56-00:00

Area: Lunenburg County, Queens County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of snow are expected Saturday night through Monday morning, with the potential for significant snowfall Sunday night. The first round of snow is expected to be fairly light. Snow will begin Saturday night with a few cm accumulating by Sunday morning. The snow will be wet and may become mixed with rain Sunday afternoon as temperatures rise above freezing. A more significant round of snow is possible beginning late Sunday afternoon. Current guidance suggests snowfall amounts near 10 cm Sunday night. However, with temperatures hovering near freezing the snow will be wet and slushy. If it is slightly warmer than expected, snow is likely to change over to rain. While there is still some uncertainty in the forecast, wet and slushy snow may make for a messy commute Monday morning. Power outages are also possible if heavy, wet snow accumulates on trees. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T10:31:40-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall: 25 to 50 cm through Saturday, with additional amounts expected into Sunday. Higher amounts possible inland. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h. Locations: southeastern Labrador from Lodge Bay to Rigolet. Time span: continuing through the weekend. Remarks: Snow will continue through today and become heavy at times tonight. The fresh snowfall will combine with strong northeasterly winds to reduce visibilities in blowing snow beginning near midnight tonight. There is currently some uncertainty as to when the storm will end. Poor travel conditions may persist through the weekend. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-23T06:48:18-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall today. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, likely higher in some areas of heaviest snow bands. Locations: Annapolis, Kings, and Halifax counties. Time span: ending this evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is falling across parts of Nova Scotia today as a small but vigorous weather system develops and passes just off the Atlantic coast. Given the nature of this system, the location of heaviest snowfall is difficult to pin down, and as such this statement may need to be extended to additional regions or upgraded to a snowfall warning for some areas. Regardless, the timing of the snow will likely have impacts on the evening commute in the Halifax Regional Municipality and the surrounding areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T02:44:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-22T15:09:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3726415083.2021
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Valemount due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-01-23T02:26:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-01-22T10:27:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0277249512.2021
Area: Yellowhead
